a device that has ABS enabled on it so this here is an echo show vertical spot

that is the wake word that is configured for this everything that after that becomes basically an utterance that
becomes what's called an intent we'll talk about that here in a little bit which will kick off ideally a skill
which will interface with the rules that I've set up talk to my back-end I generate what are called requests and
responses and then give a response back to my device and that response could be audio that response could be video it
could be a still image or it could be it taking an action such as like turning on and off the lights in that case I'm not
going expect Alexa to say I'm turning off light so I'm just going expect it to do it and so pretty straightforward kind
of logic loop here again right you as a user say something to the device Alexa do blah blah blah Alexa takes that
processes it sends a request off to your back-end back-end does what needs to do spits back a response to you says it
displays it or takes the action really pretty kind of straightforward request response flow now one of the key
technologies behind Alexa is a service that we have at AWS called Amazon Lex there's actually two services that are
key to what Alexa is one it's called Lex the other is called poly so what Lex is is a natural language understanding
service basically you can use this to create your own chat BOTS to create your own audio BOTS and again it's kind of
the core foundational understanding technology translating speech into text and deriving what it is that you're
trying to do based on that so as an example of this there's a couple of kind of core
concepts that we have one is utterances this is basically the things that you say to a voice service to tell it to do
something so you see here for example I'd like to book the car a hotel I'd like to make Hotel Reservations can
you help me book my hotel I want to book the hotel in New York City these are all phrases that we're saying that we need
there to be some sort of interpretation of via service so that it can understand what it is that we're trying to
accomplish now what this lends itself to is a concept of having what we call slots of
information so going back to the example of booking a hotel there's a bunch of information that I need an order
successfully do this where do I want to book my hotel when do I want to check in when do I want to check out there might
be all sorts of other things that I might care about here and so what a voice service like ABS does is it allows
us to do what's called slot licit ation basically allowed it to converse back with me to find and gather all the
information that it needs in order to complete what it is that I'm doing so I don't necessarily have to say all at
once Alexa I'd like to book a hotel in New York check me in on this date check me out on that date that's a whole lot to
have to say and I'd have to know that exact phrasing but instead I could start with a very basic kind of intent of what
I'm looking for and then build off of there so a way to kind of visualize this is we see here that I'd like to book a
hotel and so I say booked a hotel in New York City so I am giving you some information what will happen here is
that behind the scenes in the Alexa voice service actually powered by Amazon Lex is going to pull apart the words
that are inside of this so it sees booked a hotel in New York City and then takes that and based on language
understanding knowing how people actually speak turns those into water considered intents and or slots of
information still has to figure that out a little bit and then from here what can happen is it can understand that okay
your intent is to book a hotel in order for me to complete this intent I need to fulfill these slots of information and
this is again as a developer I've told it what those slots are and so now Alexa can come back to me and ask me questions
to fulfill basically the gathering of that slot information let's take an example like
order a pizza I could say Alexey I'd like to order a pizza it's gonna come back and say what size what toppings is
there anything else you'd like to order with it all of the questions that is asking back to me are so it can attempt
to gather lots of information at the end of it you having enough information for
the base amount of slots that it needs to complete what it needs to complete then what it can have is a confirmation
are you sure that you would like to order this large pizza with pepperoni and I can say yes or no or potentially
reply out there in other ways and then at some point since it's gathered all this information you can actually go and
place that order for me and then come back and spit out a response that says ok the pizzas on the way ok I've booked
your hotel and again Amazon Polly is a service that does text-to-speech so kind
of be inverse of what Lex does so it's kind of broad big view there's a lot of
other things that Alexa itself can do so again Alexa is a combination of a couple of core technologies then it also has
this massive AI capability built on top of all sorts of knowledge that it has consumed for many different places you
can get knowledge from Wikipedia from internet searches things from history
that it has basically digested into the wealth of knowledge that Alexa has so Alexa is a bit more complicated than
just a lexington poly there's quite a lot that she's capable of so what's
really awesome is if you have one of these devices it's actually super easy to create what's called a skill so again
a skill is one of the is a thing that Alexa can do so when I say Alexa ordered
me a pizza from dominos that is a skill Alexa check my bank account with Capital One that is a skill Alexa turn on the
lights and livingroom that is a skill and so you could very easily extend this yourself with one of these devices so
when it comes to an Alexa skill there's basically two core components there is the user interface essentially what is

from the viewpoint of the Alexa team lambda they feel is the best thing to back-end a alexis skill and actually a
very large amount of alexis skills are backed by lambda now lambda it falls into what we call service computing
products if you've been down the expo center you've seen the AWS booth we're actually here from the service product
organization sponsoring all of the go to events this year so really working and
getting out this message but what is service so it's kind of a hot term in the industry means a lot of things to a
lot of different people but for us at AWS service means basically kind of four key criteria to how we categorize
products and say what kind of does fit in the box worst what doesn't fit in the box for what service is so for us it
comes down to there being absolutely no servers to provision or manage this means no physical and the virtual no
containers even that you would have to yourself take care of and care about there's nothing below below your code
level it scales automatically with usage so in the case of an Alexis skill we
should never have to think about capacity planning if I for some reason managed to get a skill that is so amazing and it's used by everyone and
it's getting hundreds of requests per second I should never have to think about capacity planning for what that is
or if I was building an API that was processing thousands of requests per second I shouldn't have to think about
how to scale that and so our service products all fit that never having to pay that for idle is another one that is
actually one of the key key key Ferengi ators between what makes the technology service and what it doesn't so typically when you're building
back-end infrastructure for applications one of the things that you pretty much have to have to do is always have at
least one of something so you have to have at least one server always have one container always have at least something
there so when request comes in it can answer it now in many organizations what you end up having to do is capacity planning
so we know that at some point there may be X amount of requests or X amount of users we want to make sure that we could
always handle that that typically requires you you know over provisioning infrastructure and this leads to a lot
of waste in the industry in fact Gartner says that less than 80 percent are sorry less than 20 percent of IT
infrastructure is actually utilized most of its it's they're never getting requests never doing anything so never
paying for idle is a very big change in terms of the cost model perspective for server lists it'll lastly availability and fault
tolerance built-in so we don't want to have to think about having n plus 1 of something so that we have failed over we
have resiliency that we have to control in the case of the service products this is gonna be done for us so at the core
of this world for us is a product called AWS lambda part of the product team that I am part of and so lambda is a compute
service where you write code and you send it up to a salute to the service today we support five primary languages
nodejs Python Java C sharp and more recently go which came out in January and that what happens is we have some
sort of an event source in this case the Alexa voice service we're just going to send an event to lambda I'm just going
to fire up your code it's going to process that event maybe it has to talk to a database maybe has to talk to another API maybe it just has to have
logic inside of itself and then it's going to go and reply back potentially to that service or do whatever it is
that needs to do and the idea here is that you're taking a larger application and decomposing it into smaller parts so
unlike a more traditional application design where you might have many many many components inside of a single application and the world of lambda you
typically are taking a large application and having separate functions so an example of this is if you had an API
that had say 20 different capabilities or 20 actions inside of it each of those actions would align to an individual
lambda function as opposed to you just having a single code base there running now functions are pretty straightforward
in terms of what they have to look like again you provide your own code we don't have any sort of kind of control over
what it is that you do and right there are some some kind of basic constructs that you have though so one is that we
have a concept called a handler you have to tell the lambda service where your handler is in your code base so that we
know where it is that we have to start or invoke your code and then there's basically two other things that we provide to you that you can use in your
application to do whatever it is that you need to the first is the events context this is basically the
information that's coming in from your invoking source so in the case of an Alexis skill this is going to be information about whatever it is that
the request that has been going into it in the case of an API call it could be the information coming in from the API
there's a number of other things that are there and then we provide something called the context object the context
object is essentially information about this lambda functions environment how its configured where it can find logs a
number of other aspects about it these are basically kind of the three core components to a lambda function so we
can write a lambda function we can write our code and what we want to do though is make it really easy to deploy these
lambda functions now we have CLI as we have web consoles we have all sorts of other tools that you can use to do this
but back about a year or so ago we launched another tool which is growing very quickly in popularity to help with
